channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Omran Daqneesh, 5, Became a Symbol of Aleppo’s Suffering
item.description: Images of the dazed and injured child have quickly made him an emblem of the harrowing misery of Syria’s five-year-old civil war.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Syrian Government and Russia Are Accused of Using Napalm-Like Bombs
item.media:description: Reports of incendiary bombs have heightened fears in Daraya, a rebel-held suburb of Damascus.
item.description: The Syrian government and Russia are accused of using the bombs, which can cause horrific burns, in or near cities. Russia is part of a treaty banning them in civilians areas.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Protocol III of the Convention on Conventional Weapons

item.title: Hunting for a Buried Nazi Train, Polish Explorers Begin Quixotic Excavation
item.media:description: Police and railway security officials patrolled the closed area where a search is underway for a Nazi train in Walbrzych, Poland.
item.media:credit: Mikolaj Nowacki for The New York Times
item.description: A group is digging in southwestern Poland for a Nazi train said to be filled with stolen gold, gems and art, despite experts’ doubts that the train exists.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Fighting for the ‘Soul of France,’ More Towns Ban a Bathing Suit: The Burkini
item.media:description: A Muslim woman on Wednesday wore a burkini, a swimsuit that leaves only the face, hands and feet exposed, on a beach in Marseille, France.
item.description: The full-body bathing suit has become a flash point in a nation at odds with its Muslim population in the face of a series of terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: U.N. Admits Role in Cholera Epidemic in Haiti
item.media:description: Protesters marching to the United Nations base housing Nepalese peacekeepers in Mirebalais, Haiti, on Oct. 29, 2010.
item.description: The acknowledgment came after a confidential report told the secretary general that the outbreak, which began in 2010, “would not have broken out but for the actions of the United Nations.”
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN M. KATZ
item.category: United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti

item.title: American Swimmers Pulled Off Plane in Rio
item.media:description: From left, the U.S. swimmers Michael Phelps, Ryan Lochte and Townley Haas last week. Mr. Lochte said that he and three other swimmers, including Mr. Conger and Mr. Bentz, were robbed at gunpoint Sunday by men who identified themselves as police officers.
item.description: A judge had issued an order to seize passports as doubts emerged over reports United States swimmers had been robbed.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: ‘No Matter What You Did, You Are My Son’: Afghan Fighters Reunite as Family
item.media:description: Said Muhammad, a Taliban fighter, right, surrendered his arms to his father, Abdul Basir, an Afghan government militia commander, after years of fighting between the two.
item.description: Three months ago, Abdul Basir, a government militia commander, tried to kill his son, a Taliban fighter. This week, they were breaking bread together.
item.dc:creator: ZAHRA NADER and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Istalif Journal: War and Pillaging Couldn’t Break an Afghan Village, but a Tumbling Economy May
item.media:description: Potters and vendors on the main street of Istalif, Afghanistan, in June.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Istalif’s resurgence after the fall of the Taliban in 2001 hardened the reputation for resilience it earned over centuries, but now it is threatened again.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Nigeria, Battling Boko Haram, Detains Some of Its Victims
item.media:description: Displaced people taking shelter from the rain at a camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in June.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: South Sudan’s Opposition Leader Flees Country as Peace Deal Unravels
item.media:description: The opposition leader Riek Machar in Jonglei State, South Sudan, in 2014.
item.description: Riek Machar was being targeted by government troops, his spokesmen said, and will soon travel to Ethiopia and try to rebuild support from there.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Australia Will Close Detention Center on Manus Island, but Still Won’t Accept Asylum Seekers
item.media:description: A detention center financed by Australia on Manus Island, in Papua New Guinea, in 2012. Neither country indicated when the center would close or what would happen to the people being held there.
item.media:credit: Australian Department of Immigration and Citizenship, via Getty Images
item.description: Australia has sent hundreds of asylum seekers to the center, in Papua New Guinea, but neither country indicated what would happen to the people held there.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Sydney Morning Herald Faces Uncertain Print Future in Australia
item.media:description: The Sydney Morning Herald, in 1950, used its own plane to distribute newspapers to remote areas throughout Australia.
item.description: The decline of Fairfax Media, The Herald’s publisher and one of Australia’s two dominant media companies, has dismayed many citizens.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: 2 Officials in Vietnam Are Killed in Rare Shooting
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc of Vietnam, second from left, with a shooting victim in the northern province of Yen Bai on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Vietnam News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A province’s Communist party secretary and the chairman of a lawmaking body were shot dead in their offices by a forest ranger, who later shot himself. The motive was unknown.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Sinosphere: Choice of Hong Kong for Organ Transplant Meeting Defended
item.media:description: Fang Hui, 28, showing the scar from a living donor organ transplant operation in which she received a portion of her sister’s liver. China is trying to encourage voluntary donations to replace its longstanding reliance on organs from executed prisoners.
item.description: Organizers said the move did not signify international acceptance of China’s transplant system, which long relied on organs from executed prisoners.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Thomas Cholmondeley, Scion Implicated in Deaths of 2 Kenyans, Dies at 48
item.media:description: Thomas Cholmondeley, second from right, during his sentencing in Nairobi, Kenya, in 2009.
item.description: A descendant of British settlers, Mr. Cholmondeley was known as an eccentric outdoorsman who liked fast horses, speedy bikes and guns.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: 11 Killed in Attacks on Police, Military in Turkey; 226 Hurt
item.description: A string of bombings, blamed on Kurdish rebels and targeting Turkey's security forces, killed at least 11 people and wounded 226 others, officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Coal Burning Causes the Most Air Pollution Deaths in China, Study Finds
item.media:description: Sorting through coal at a mine in Shanxi, China, last year. Coal is responsible for about 40 percent of the deadly fine particulate matter known as PM 2.5 in China’s atmosphere, a study found.
item.description: The fuel was responsible for 366,000 premature deaths in the country in 2013, Chinese and American researchers concluded.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: U.N. Wants to Know Why Peacekeepers Did Not Stop Violence in South Sudan
item.description: The secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, has ordered an independent inquiry into a spate of violence last month, including the rapes and beatings of foreign aid workers.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Hedge Funds Avoided Big Losses Despite ‘Brexit’ Shock
item.media:description: London’s financial district on June 25, the Saturday after Britain’s surprising vote to leave the European Union.
item.media:credit: Marco Kesseler for The New York Times
item.description: Britain’s vote to leave the European Union sent many fund managers scrambling, but managers cite a number of factors that help explain how some avoided losses.
item.dc:creator: ANITA RAGHAVAN

item.title: Egypt Suspends 8 Female TV Anchors, Saying They Are Overweight
item.description: The director of state-run Egyptian radio and television barred the women from appearing on the air for a month, and ordered them to go on a diet.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Leading the Edinburgh Fringe: ‘I’m Not Intimidated’
item.media:description: Shona McCarthy, chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society.
item.media:credit: Robert Ormerod for The New York Times
item.description: Shona McCarthy discusses her new job, how to best accommodate artists, and her plans for this festival’s 70th anniversary next summer.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN McELROY

item.title: Sinosphere: Where Mao Meets the Mundane: Everyday Life in a Bygone China
item.media:description: Friends on an outing in Beihai Park in Beijing in 1968, at the height of the Cultural Revolution. This photo and others collected by Covell Meyskens provide a more nuanced look at the experience of ordinary Chinese during this time.
item.description: The historian Covell Meyskens discusses his blog, where he displays photos and other documents from the first decades of Communist rule.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: German Who Plotted to Bomb U.S. Targets in Europe Gets Out of Prison Early
item.media:description: Fritz Martin Gelowicz in Düsseldorf, Germany, in March 2010, when he was sentenced to 12 years in prison. He was released this week.
item.description: Fritz Gelowicz, who had trained with an offshoot of Al Qaeda in Pakistan, received a 12-year sentence in 2010.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Visiting Beijing, Myanmar’s Aung San Suu Kyi Seeks to Mend Relations
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, center, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate credited with pushing Myanmar toward democracy, at a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Vientiane, Laos, in July.
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: With her first visit to a major capital since becoming leader of Myanmar, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi signaled that her foreign policy would be more friendly toward China.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and WAI MOE

item.title: A.N.C., Losing Its Hold on Cities, Fails to Form Coalition in Johannesburg
item.media:description: Julius Malema, center, the leader of the Economic Freedom Fighters opposition party, in Johannesburg on Wednesday. He called the African National Congress “corrupt to the core.”
item.description: Before the Aug. 3 elections, South Africa’s long-governing African National Congress held outright majorities in most of the largest cities. It now risks being shut out of power there.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Debate Flares on China’s Use of Prisoners’ Organs as Experts Meet in Hong Kong
item.media:description: Huang Jiefu, center, a senior Chinese transplant official and a former deputy minister of health, and his colleagues bow before a deceased patient who was willing to donate her organs, in 2012.
item.description: Some doctors and ethicists say an international transplant conference should not be held in Hong Kong given the controversy.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: International Congress of the Transplantation Society

item.title: Turkey to Release Tens of Thousands of Prisoners to Make Room for Coup Suspects
item.media:description: The Sincan prison near Ankara, Turkey, in 2012. The country said in a decree on Wednesday that it would begin releasing up to 38,000 prisoners, or roughly one in five behind bars.
item.description: The government said in a decree that it would begin freeing up to 38,000 nonviolent offenders to make way for detainees including journalists, teachers, lawyers and judges.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Vietnam Changes Course and Will Allow Veterans’ Ceremony at Long Tan
item.media:description: Ernie Gimm, right, an Australian veteran, with friends in Vung Tau, Vietnam, on Wednesday.
item.description: After a personal appeal from Australia’s prime minister, about 1,000 veterans from Australia and New Zealand will be permitted to mark the bloody battle’s 50th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Auschwitz Survivors, in Their 90s, Urge Germany to Act on War Crimes Case
item.media:description: Oskar Gröning, a former German SS officer, was sentenced last year to four years in prison for accessory to murder, but the decision has been appealed.
item.description: A group has asked the country’s highest court to swiftly resolve the case of Oskar Gröning, a former SS soldier whose conviction over complicity in the murder of 300,000 is under appeal.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: North Korea’s No. 2 Diplomat in London Defects to the South
item.media:description: Jeong Joon-hee, above, a South Korean government spokesman, said that the defection of the diplomat Thae Yong-ho was “a sign that some of the core elite in the North are losing hope in the Kim Jong-un regime.”
item.description: Thae Yong-ho is the most senior diplomat to flee the secretive nation since Jang Seung-gil, the envoy to Egypt, defected to the United States in 1997.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Cross-Border Fire From Yemen Kills 7 in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The attack appears to have been staged by Houthi militias in northern Yemen in retaliation for a series of deadly airstrikes by the Saudi-led military coalition.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere: Revamped Chinese History Journal Welcomes Hard-Line Writers
item.media:description: Wang Yanjun, who was ousted as deputy editor of Yanhuang Chunqiu, with the latest issue of the journal on Tuesday, which still shows his name and that of other editors removed by its new managers. Several former editors are trying to sue the journal’s government sponsor to wrest back control.
item.description: The new editors of the magazine, Yanhuang Chunqiu, appear likely to remake what had been one of the few remaining outlets for liberal political opinion in China.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: What’s That on Your Bumper? A Hairy Kind of Car Insurance
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by Bruno Ferrari, Cammep, ArtHeart/Shutterstock
item.description: Ponytails are attached to taxis for strength and good fortune in West Africa. Religious icons are also popular blessings for safe travel.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: Stardom in India Has Its Price: Thousands of Gallons of Milk
item.media:description: Fans spraying milk on a poster of the Indian film star Rajinikanth to celebrate the screening of his latest film last month in Mumbai.
item.description: For decades, fans of the Tamil actor Shivaji Rao Gaekwad, better known as Rajinikanth, have bathed pictures of him in milk, a sign of devotion. Milk dealers, however, would like to see it stop.
item.dc:creator: AYESHA VENKATARAMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: France Has the Burkini Blues
item.description: Banning burkinis is a mistake but French Muslims must demonstrate they accept the core values of secular France.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Calling Al Qaeda’s Bluff
item.media:description: Members of Jabhat Fatah al-Sham — formerly Jabhat al-Nusra — near Aleppo, Syria, this month.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The rebranding of the terrorist group’s affiliate in Syria can’t be taken at face value.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN IBISH

item.title: Editorial: Dimming Hope for Afghan Translators
item.description: Ending a visa program that granted a safe haven for interpreters would be reckless and morally reprehensible.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Brazil Bureau Chief’s Notebook: When the Olympics Media Circus Comes to Town
item.media:description: Residents of the Mangueira neighborhood in Rio de Janeiro watched fireworks during the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Some of the impressions expressed by journalists parachuting in for the Games call to mind the Onion headline “Woman Who ‘Loves Brazil’ Has Only Seen Four Square Miles of It.”
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Skala Sikaminias Journal: Greek Villagers Rescued Migrants. Now They Are the Ones Suffering.
item.media:description: The keeper of the main church in Skala Sikaminias, Lesbos, looked out to sea. Some villagers say that when they look at the horizon, they often think that another refugee boat is coming.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: The island of Lesbos was ground zero for refugees flooding across the Aegean. A year later, the imprint of that experience still affects one village that tried to help.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
